rsbNotes.title: Ex 25:1–31:8
rsbNotes.text: 25:1–31:8 This section goes into great detail regarding the divine pattern for the place where the Lord Himself would dwell among His people. The tabernacle and its ministry are the two central features—details of the tabernacle construction, and the precise elements, manner, and persons to be employed in God’s service are carefully specified. The inauguration of the covenant had established God’s kingship over Israel. That kingship was now to be appropriately recognized by the building of a residence for God as a symbol of His royal authority over Israel.

rsbNotes.title: Ex 30:12
rsbNotes.text:
30:12 take the census. The half-shekel atonement money that accompanied each census witnessed to Israel’s dependence on the Lord’s mercy. Their lives were forfeit because of sin, and must be redeemed. The lesson of the Passover and the redemption of the firstborn is applied to all Israel (13:15; 22:29; Num. 3:40–51).

ransom. Lit. “atonement.” The payment served as an act of individual atonement and was an assertion of God’s rights over Israel.

rsbNotes.title: Ex 30:13
rsbNotes.text: 30:13 half a shekel. In difficult times the amount was apparently reduced (Neh. 10:32).

rsbNotes.title: Ex 30:17–21
rsbNotes.text: 30:17–21 The priests washed their hands and feet when they approached the altar or entered the tabernacle for ministry. No dimensions are given for the basin, though Solomon’s temple basins were massive (1 Kin. 7:38). Neglecting to wash might cause death—the holy God was not to be approached casually (vv. 20, 21).

rsbNotes.title: Ex 31:1–11
rsbNotes.text: 31:1–11 The tabernacle was to be constructed according to the divine design by gifted men who were supernaturally enabled by the Holy Spirit to do all the tasks required (vv. 3–6, 11). All the work was described to Moses by God and little room was left for creative variation (25:9).

rsbNotes.title: Ex 31:2
rsbNotes.text: 31:2 Bezalel. The name is archaic and means “in El’s [God’s] shadow” (cf. 17:10 note).

rsbNotes.title: Ex 31:6
rsbNotes.text: 31:6 Oholiab. Bezalel’s assistant. His name means “the father is my tent.”

rsbNotes.title: Ex 31:12–17
rsbNotes.text: 31:12–17 The Sabbath commandment is reiterated and designated as the covenant sign of the Mosaic covenant (Gen. 9:12 note). To keep God’s Sabbath is to keep the covenant since the Sabbath is a sign of the special relationship between God and Israel. To disregard God’s Sabbath was to disregard God’s purposes for creation through His redemption of Israel.

rsbNotes.title: Ex 31:18
rsbNotes.text:
31:18 two tablets of the testimony. See note Deut. 5:22. Some suggest that these were two identical copies. Consistent with ancient Near Eastern suzerainty treaties, one copy belonged to each treaty partner and the copies were housed in the respective sanctuaries. The ark was both the focal point of Israel’s sanctuary and the special dwelling place of God. Hence, both copies were placed in the ark.

finger of God. See 8:19.
